- Reasoning: This study arm aims to demonstrate the efficacy of hot EMR in removing large colonic adenomas without the need for resection. By heating the lesion, the tissue can be removed in a more controlled manner.

Study Arm 2:
- Participant Group/Arm: Cold EMR
- Intervention/Treatment: In this technique, a snare wire is placed around the target lesion, and the polyp is then removed using a mechanical traction or the cutting mode of the polypectomy snare.
- Reasoning: This study arm serves as the control group for comparison with the hot EMR technique. By removing the lesion mechanically without using heat, we can assess the effectiveness of the traditional method.

For the experimental arm, I suggest using the Cold EMR technique. This involves preparing a deep submucosal injection of physiological solution mixed with methylene blue and insulin. The polypoid lesion is then resected using a diathermic snare with a cutting current. Finally, the margins are fulgurated with a current of 20 to 25 milliamperes. This arm will help assess the effectiveness of the novel cold EMR technique and compare it to the standard hot EMR technique.

For Maitland's mobilization technique, we can include gentle kneadings, pressure, and stretching techniques performed in short amplitude with minimal speed. This will be combined with MW, a specific Maitland's technique focused on the area of the menisci and articular capsule to identify areas of restricted motion. This treatment will aim to restore mobility in the affected knee joint.

Interferential therapy involves the use of a specific device that emits electric currents. The parameters for the therapy include an intermittent wave, pulse width of 1500 to 2500 Hz and amplitude of 3-4mA. We can set a constant frequency of 70Hz with a pulse duration of 120 seconds and intensity of 0.5 W/Cm2 using a low intensity interferential device.

Certainly! Mulligan's mobilization technique consists of five components: distraction, active joint glides to gain an active range of joint motion, passive joint glides, pain and muscle guarding assessments, and application of Mulligan's techniques (i.e., intra-articular thrust, interosseous stretch).

The interferential therapy parameters for the active comparator group are identical to those of the experimental group, that is: carrier frequency 4000Hz, waveform rectangular, sweep time 1 second rise and fall and 5-second stay, treatment duration 10 minutes, sweep frequency 10 to 130 Hz, and adjustment of the current intensity until a strong tingling sensation without causing muscle contraction. A aquatic gel will also be applied before strapping the electropads over the treatment area.

- Intervention/Treatment: Oxaliplatin and Capecitabine

Title: Renal Denervation in Patients With Recurrent Atrial Fibrillation After Successful Pulmonary Vein Isolation
Conditions: Arrhythmia burden in patients with recurrent, paroxysmal atrial fibrillation despite durable pulmonary vein isolation
Intervention/Treatment: Device: Catheter-based renal denervation for hypertension (SPYRAL)
Study Type: Interventional
Phase: Not Applicable
Criteria: Inclusion criteria: 1. Informed Consent signed by the subject. 2. ≥ 18 years of age. 3. Recurrent, paroxysmal atrial fibrillation post repeat (≥2) pulmonary vein isolation. 4. Documentation of atrial fibrillation ≥3 months after the last atrial fibrillation ablation procedure by a 12-lead ECG or on a rhythm strip of ≥30 seconds duration. 5. Either an office systolic blood pressure ≥130 mmHg at the screening visit or antihypertensive drug therapy. 6. Signed written informed consent. 7. All other inclusion criteria for the SPYRAL HTN-OFF MED study must apply (documented antihypertensive drug therapy, 12-lead ECG in absence of symptoms of atrial fibrillation, and office SBP≥130 mmHg). 8. Able and willing to self-monitor blood pressure at home and complete the patient-reported outcome questionnaire in the SPYRAL HTN-OFF MED study at predefined appointments. Exclusion criteria: 1. Persistent or permanent atrial fibrillation post pulmonary vein isolation. 2. Left ventricular ejection fraction <40%. 3. Severe aortic or mitral valve stenosis. 4. Treatment with amiodarone within the last 3 months. 5. Mandatory treatment with class I or III antiarrhythmic drugs. 6. History of syncope or orthostatic hypotension. 7. Prior renal denervation.

model_response: Certainly! In Part A - Escalation, we will explore the recommended phase 2 dose of tepotinib in combination with pembrolizumab in Chinese patients. This arm is crucial for determining the optimal dosage for subsequent phases of the trial. The design involves dose escalation or expansion, with a maximum of four dose escalations. This approach allows for the identification of any dose-limiting toxicities and the determination of the optimal dose for the next phase.

In Part B - Expansion, we will enroll patients who have either received only one line of systemic therapy for metastatic disease or have progressed following treatment with Tepotinib in Part A (escalation). This arm will focus on determining the efficacy of the combination treatment in NSCLC patients who have specific molecular alterations. It will provide valuable information on the effectiveness of the treatment in targeting specific biomarkers and evaluating the overall response rate and progression-free survival.

In Part A - Escalation, patients will be given a dose of 300 mg of Tepotinib per day orally. Pembrolizumab will be given intravenously at a dose of 200 mg every three weeks. The administration will continue until disease progression, unacceptable toxic effects, death, consent withdrawal, or loss to follow-up. Additionally, patients who receive 150 mg of Tepotinib per day orally and develop adverse effects at the 28th day will receive a maximum of 250 mg per day orally until disease progression or an increased adverse effect grade.

In Part B - Expansion, patients will receive Tepotinib daily at the Maximum Tolerable Dose (MTD). Pembrolizumab immunotherapy will be given every three weeks. The treatment will continue for at least 45 days after surgery in patients undergoing resection or until disease progression, death or unacceptable toxicity.

Certainly! Here are the full study arms:

It is a novel approach in the treatment of relapsed/refractory multiple myeloma. By modifying T cells to target GPRC5D-positive cells, we aim to harness the patient's own immune system to fight the cancer. This strategy has shown promise in preclinical studies and has the potential to be a highly effective therapy for these patients.

These CARs enable the T cells to recognize and attack cancer cells, specifically those expressing the targeted antigen. In this case, the targeted antigen is GPRC5D. ICI201 CAR-T cell injection involves the intravenous infusion of autologous (patient's own) CAR-T cells that have been engineered to express a CAR specific for GPRC5D. The goal is to use these modified T cells to target multiple myeloma cells and induce an anti-tumor immune response.

- Intervention/Treatment: Procedure: Elective endoscopic gallbladder treatment
- Description: This arm includes patients with benign gallbladder diseases and high surgical risk who are undergoing endoscopically guided intramural gallbladder puncture. The goal of this procedure is to relieve symptomatic cholecystitis, prevent symptomatic gallbladder stones, and eliminate potential surgical risks.

Certainly! In this arm, the intervention will include two main procedures: 
- Endoscopic gallbladder drainage: This procedure involves inserting LAMS into the cystic duct and gallbladder. Once the LAMS are in place, if needed, endoscopic lithotripsy using different methods will be performed to achieve stone disintegration. If any complications arise, such as LAMS migration or re-obstructions, subsequent interventions such as LAMS repositioning or ERCP may be required. 

- Endoscopic lithotripsy: Depending on the size or location of the gallbladder stones, different methods may be used to perform lithotripsy, including D-JET (pneumatic disintegrative devices), or a combination of D-JET and EHL (electrohydraulic lithotripter) procedures. During this procedure, bile duct manometry will be performed to assess pressure changes and evaluate stone disintegration. If needed, endoscopic gallbladder drainage will be performed again.

Certainly! Here are the full study arms:

- Intervention/Treatment: Endoscopic gallbladder drainage under EUS guidance using LAMS followed, when needed, by endoscopic lithotripsy. Access to the gallbladder will be performed from the stomach or duodenum using a LAMS with an electrocautery-enhanced delivery system such as Hot Axios or Hot Spaxus. The size of the stent used will depend on the size of the largest gallstone, with a 10 mm diameter stent used for gallstones smaller than 10 mm and a larger diameter (≥15 mm stent) used for gallstones larger than 10 mm. If needed, colecystoscopy lithotripsy will be performed using mechanical lithotripsy and/or laser lithotripsy. The first cholecystoscopy will be done 2 weeks after the initial procedure.

model_response: Sure. For the experimental arm, the participant group would be individuals with a cervical level spinal cord injury. They should be sedentary to active individuals living with a spinal cord injury ranging from T7 to C4. We should include this group to evaluate the physiological effects of passive heat therapy on arterial stiffness and cardiovascular risk in higher level (cervical) spinal cord injury. How does that sound?

For the intervention/treatment in the experimental arm, we can use Behavioral: Passive Heating as the primary therapy. By heating the lower body by immersion in warm (40°C) water in a tub, we aim to stimulate capillary dilatation in the skin, which increases blood flow to lower extremities and legs. This approach is known to be cardioprotective in individuals with higher-level spinal cord injuries because of their increased risk of CVD with long-term immobility.

Absolutely! The experimental arm is designed to test the hypothesis that an acute bout of mild exercise-like heating response achieved through hot tub immersion can improve endothelial function and function of the immune system, which are impaired following a spinal cord injury. By simulating a mild exercise response with a passive heating intervention, we aim to assess the potential cardioprotective benefits of this approach in individuals with higher-level spinal cord injury.

For the control group/arm, we can include non-disabled healthy individuals. This will allow us to compare the outcomes of the intervention group with individuals who do not have spinal cord injuries. By including a control group, we can assess whether any changes observed in the experimental arm are specific to individuals with spinal cord injuries or if they are generalizable to the overall population.

Certainly! Here are the full study arms:

Study Arms:
1. Experimental: Passive Heating
   - Group/Arm: Individuals living with a spinal cord injury between T7 and C4 levels
   - Intervention/Treatment: Behavioral: Passive Heating
     - Passive heating achieved by immersion in a hot tub at 40 degrees Celsius for approximately 45 minutes

2. Control: Non-disabled healthy adult
   - Group/Arm: Non-disabled healthy individuals matched for age
   - Intervention/Treatment: None (No passive heating)

Please note that the control group will receive no intervention other than the standard COVID-19 pre-screening survey and consent procedures.

The procedure would involve using a 5-10 ml/kg bolus of bupivacaine 0.32% with fentanyl 5 mcg/ml 0.05 ml/kg to a total dose of 100 ml. The block needle would be connected to an elastotape and secured in position after needle withdrawal. A catheter would be left in place, and analgesia would be provided by infusing 1 ml/kg/hr of bupivacaine 0.32% with fentanyl 5 mcg/ml to provide continuous analgesia for 4 days.

The SAP block is a commonly used regional analgesic technique that provides multisegmental analgesia to the thoracic wall. It has been shown to be effective in reducing pain scores and opioid consumption in patients with rib fractures. We want to evaluate its efficacy in providing pain relief compared to dexmedetomidine infusion, which is the treatment in the second study arm.

The second study arm is the Active Comparator: DEX group. In this arm, patients will receive an intravenous dexmedetomidine infusion for pain management. This arm is included to compare the efficacy and safety of dexmedetomidine infusion with the SAP block in managing pain in patients with multiple rib fractures. Dexmedetomidine is a long-acting alpha-2 adrenergic agonist that has been shown to provide effective pain relief and sedation in similar patient populations.
